Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or credible sources to support the assertion that money was discarded on the streets of Italy during the Covid-19 pandemic.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the photos shared on social media depict money discarded on the streets of Italy during the pandemic, without verifying the authenticity or context of the images.
Contradict fact: The photos shared in the misleading Facebook post are actually of old Venezuelan currency notes that are no longer in use, contradicting the claim that they represent money discarded in Italy during the pandemic.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the situation by presenting false information about money being thrown on the streets of Italy, when the photos actually depict old Venezuelan currency notes.
Falters at times: The claim falters in providing accurate information by misinterpreting the images and presenting them as evidence of money being discarded in Italy during the pandemic.
Exist alternative explanation: The alternative explanation is that the photos shared on social media actually show old Venezuelan currency notes that were vandalized or discarded in Venezuela, not in Italy during the pandemic.
